metadata.background_text:
MONICA!
The White House may have been in crisis all year, but the events were less the stuff of great drama than of a farcical musical comedy. Hey, wait a minute--let's put on a show! 

                         The time: November 1995.              

                         The House Republicans, led by Speaker Newt Gingrich, are insisting on their version of the budget. President Bill Clinton is stubbornly rejecting it. The Republicans have taken a bold option: They will just refuse to pass a budget, and they'll let the government shut down. In the Oval Office, BILL CLINTON meets with advisers LEON PANETTA and HAROLD ICKES and secretary BETTY CURRIE to discuss this development.              

         "The Shutdown" (upbeat production number) 

                         PANETTA: The Republicans have positions 

         To which they're clinging fast. 

                         ICKES: The president is just as firm 

         The die, it seems, is cast. 

                         PANETTA: Without a budget passed by Congress 

         The government will close. 

         All of the workers 

         Will be sent home on furloughs. 

                         CLINTON 

            [speaking]                : Well, wait a second--not all of them. We'll need to keep some essential personnel. 

                         PANETTA: The Army and the Navy 

         Will need to stay in place. 

                         ICKES: Also those at NASA 

         Who keep the shuttle up in space. 

                         PANETTA: We'll need to keep the pilots 

         Flying in their planes. 

                         CLINTON: And here at the White House 

         My staff should remain. 

                         PANETTA 

            [speaking]                : But even here at the White House, some adjustments will be required. 

                         CLINTON: OK, tell the ushers 

         To take a few days off. 

         Tell the maids and cooks and butlers 

         To go play themselves some golf. 

         We have to do without the clerks 

         Let them all go home. 

                         CURRIE: What about the secretaries? 

         Who will get the phones? 

                         CLINTON 

            [speaking]                : We've got to make sure the Oval Office functions with efficiency. We can't afford the tiniest error. 

                         PANETTA: Aha! I have it! 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         Someone who's an expert with a phone. 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         We'll bring in an intern, 

         I assure you, Mr. President-- 

         Your routine here won't get blown. 

                         PANETTA , ICKES , and CURRIE                 [solemnly agreeing]                :              

         The presence of an intern will ensure 

         Your routine here won't get blown. 

          

            [The advisers depart, leaving President Clinton alone. He turns introspective.]              

         "President Lonely" (a ballad) 

                         CLINTON: I've got deputies and bureaucrats 

         Who fulfill my every thought. 

         And soldiers, sailors, and Marines 

         To fight battles I want fought. 

         There's no one who's got more power, 

         I'm the leader of all that's free 

         But if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I'm just 

         Lonely. 

         I'm President Lonely. 

         But I guess I'll just have to muddle through. 

         The cheers and applause are overwhelming, 

         But presidents need cuddles, too. 

         The fawning adoration's pleasant, 

         But presidents need cuddles, too. 

                         [Enter Betty Currie.]              

                         CURRIE: Mr. President? The intern is here. And she's brought you some pizza! 

                         [The lights go down. When they resume, the intern-- MONICA LEWINSKY --is talking on the phone to her good friend LINDA TRIPP .]              

                         LEWINSKY: Well, y'know, I'd seen him around, like, a lot. And I know he noticed me. So when they said they needed an intern to answer the phones, I said, "Hel-lo-o-o!" And then I had the idea to take him pizza! 

          

            TRIPP: And then what happened? 

         "What Went On" (upbeat) 

                         LEWINSKY: Then I led him on. 

         I showed him my thong, 

         I let him take a long and ling'ring look. 

         I led him on. 

         He studied my thong, 

         And from that point I had the president hooked. 

         That night when I took the president some pizza, 

         I made sure that he knew that he could have a piece. 

         We went into the hallway by his study 

         And dispensed with formalities. 

                         TRIPP: Oh please go on! 

         You must go on! 

         Come on, girlfriend, 

         Spill, spill, spill, spill, spill! 

         Now go on, 

         Please go on. 

         Did Clinton let you say hi to Little Bill? 

           

                         LEWINSKY: His lips and mine locked in a kiss fantastic, 

         His hands roved freely 'neath my blouse, 

         I reached into the presidential trousers, 

         And he got a phone call from a member of the House. 

         So I went on, 

         While he talked on the phone, 

         I took a position before him on my knees, 

         And I went on. 

         And he talked on. 

         Though what the congressman heard was 

          "Please, please, please, please, please!" 

         But then we didn't go on! 

                         TRIPP: You didn't go on? 

                         LEWINSKY: No, he stopped me when he seemed upon the cusp. 

                         TRIPP: So you didn't go on? 

                         LEWINSKY: No, we didn't go on. 

         He said he wasn't sure if I was someone he 

         Could 

         Trust. 

                         [The lights fade as the girlfriends engage in cross talk.]              

                         TRIPP: Trust? 

                         LEWINSKY: That's why we didn't go on. 

                         TRIPP: That's so weird! What did he think? That you'd go blabbin' this to the whole world? 

                         LEWINSKY: I mean--rilly! Hey, what's that clicking? 

                         TRIPP: It's just my gum. 

                         LEWINSKY: Oh--OK! 

                         [As the relationship between Clinton and Monica continues, some members of the White House staff become worried about the prudence of continuing the relationship with so much potential for scandal. This song is a conversation between Betty Currie, who, though worried, still thinks Monica is a good person, and the rather stonier EVELYN LIEBERMAN .]              

         "Time to Go" 

                         CURRIE: They go back there, 

         They're just talking, 

         I'm sure she has a very thirsty mind. 

                         LIEBERMAN: I don't mind a girl who thinks, 

         It's just what she picks to drink. 

         Betty, it's Lewinsky's time to go. 

                         CURRIE: She brings him 

         Little presents. 

         She really is a very thoughtful soul. 

                         LIEBERMAN: It's not the junk I mind as much 

         As her up real close and personal touch. 

         I tell ya, it's Miss Monica's time to go. 

                         CURRIE: She never comes 

         When he's really busy. 

         Rarely is there anyone around. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Still the Secret Service wears a frown. 

         They shouldn't worry, he pats her down. 

         But I'm not kidding, it's time for her to go. 

                         CURRIE: Maybe she would like the Pentagon. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Good idea--don't wait! 

                         CURRIE: Studly guys work at the Pentagon. 

                         LIEBERMAN: Let's get Clinton's head on straight! 

                         CURRIE: He comes back 

         From Easter services, 

         Soon she's bopping in the door. 

                         LIEBERMAN: "Hallelujah, He Is Risen" 

         Shouldn't inspire thoughts so sizzlin'. 

         Yes, it's really time for Monica to go. 

          

            [Times passes. Monica moves to the Pentagon, but the relationship intermittently continues. Meanwhile, Paula Jones sues the president for sexual harassment, and it seems clear that before long, Clinton will have to testify under oath. Two close observers of those developments are old friends Linda Tripp and LUCIENNE GOLDBERG , who is friendly with lawyers for Jones and lawyers in the office of Independent Counsel KENNETH STARR . One day, Tripp and Goldberg talk on the phone.]              

         "Talk, Talk, Chat, Chat" (sprightly) 

                         GOLDBERG and TRIPP: Talk, talk, 

         Chat, chat, 

         Two old galpals swap the latest word. 

         Talk, talk, 

         Chat, chat, 

         Two old girlfriends dish the latest dirt. 

                         GOLDBERG: I got tickets 

         To the opera, 

         Bloomie's says I've got $40 due, 

         I lost a filling 

         At lunch on Thursday. 

         That's it for me, 

         Now tell me what's up with you. 

                         TRIPP: My friend Monica? 

         From the White House? 

         I'm pretty sure what she's saying here is true. 

         It seems this Monica chick 

         Has been sucking the president's-- 

                         GOLDBERG: Oh that's sick! 

                         TRIPP: And the two of them are going to lie about it, 

         Too. 

                         GOLDBERG: Back up, Linda, 

         Did I hear you rightly? 

         Clinton got into an intern's pants? 

         God, this news is manna, Linda! 

         At last our cause will finally have it's chance! 

                         TRIPP: Oh, you're a dreamer Luci! 

         There'll be headlines, then he'll pull off an 

         Escape. 

         He'll spin the story, he'll turn the tables-- 

                         GOLDBERG: Unless you get that airhead down on tape. 

                         TRIPP: What? 

                         GOLDBERG: Unless you get that silly, vapid, trampy time bomb 

         Down on tape. 

                         TRIPP: Oh--one more thing ... 

                         GOLDBERG: What? 

                         TRIPP: There's a dress ... 

                         GOLDBERG: Hold on, let me call Sparky. 

          

            [Independent Counsel Starr uses Tripp to detain Monica. A few days later, the news breaks. On the advice of his pal Harry Thomason, Clinton flat-out lies to his wife, to his loyalists, and to the public about the relationship.]              

         "I Never Have" (performance should build in tempo and intensity) 

                         CLINTON: You know I'd like to answer questions, 

         An act my lawyers won't allow. 

         I'll give you more not less, sooner not later, 

         I just can't say a word right now. 

         But I don't know why she'd say these things 

         Her head's full of who knows what. But I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that n-- 

         Starr has spent $40 million, 

         There's desperation on his face. 

         An utter waste of public money, 

         A prosecutorial disgrace. 

         All he's got is some recordings 

         Made by a vengeful snitch. 

         I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that b-- 

         A vast right-wing conspiracy 

         Is using her to beat on me. 

         They wanna torpedo my agenda 

         They hate me and Hillary. 

         But I will never let them ruin 

         Our dreams for a better world. 

         I tell ya, I never had sex with that woman 

         I never had sex with that 

         Girl. 

          

            [Months of investigation, legal wrangling, and public relations campaigning follow. Starr's tactics come under heavy fire, to which he responds.]              

         "Crossing the Line" 

                         STARR: It's true Monica asked to lawyer up, 

         Which Bittman put the lid on. 

         And I felt bad about her mommy's grilling 

         Upon our little gridiron. 

         The Democrats and liberals 

         Blast these tactics of mine, 

         But a man's gotta do what a man's gotta do 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         Only a fool wouldn't stretch the rules 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         It may have seemed like dirty pool 

         To drag his people 'fore the jury. 

         We wasted lots of Vernon's time, 

         May have busted Bettie Currie. 

         His aides aren't the innocent bystanders 

         As they claim when they moan and whine. 

         They won't say what they know full well: 

         The president crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         He's crossed the line. 

         I'd be a nitwit not to bend a bit 

         When the president crosses the line. 

         The talking heads are accusing me 

         Of laying a perjury trap. 

         But all it catches is lying men. 

         Honest men beat the rap. 

         There's people who say I'm against sex; 

         I've had sex. It's fine. 

         But lying about it gets my blood up 

         And the president's crossed the line. 

         I crossed the line. 

         I crossed the line. 

         Tell Steve Brill I'll leak at will 

         When the president crosses the line. 

          

            [After months of denials and futile delays, Clinton finally testifies before the Starr grand jury and argues that, technically, he didn't lie.]              

         "Testimony" (snappy) 

                         CLINTON: Depends what the definition of "is" is, 

         Depends on the meaning of sex, 

         "Alone together" is literal nonsense, 

         Before you reach conclusions, read your text. 

                         [Afterward, he speaks to the nation, admits doing wrong, and apologizes, though grudgingly.]              

                         CLINTON: Inappropriate was the nature of our actions, 

         And believe me I regret the whole damn thing, 

         But inappropriate are all these personal questions, 

         The country doesn't need to know these things. 

          

            [Clinton's enemies reject his apology, and soon the House of Representatives begins the long process of impeachment. NEWT GINGRICH here discloses his approach.]              

         "Bring 'em Down" (dark, moody) 

                         GINGRICH: Mustn't seem to be too cheerful, 

         Mustn't overreach, 

         Must remember to seem unhappy 

         That we're going to impeach. 

         Must remember to remain sober 

         As we undertake this chore. 

         At the same time, let's remember 

         To pin some stuff on Gore. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Sure, they were elected, 

         Twice, in point of fact. 

         Voters obviously were bewildered 

         To have made a choice like that. 

         Now, like charging linemen, 

         We'll move in for the sack. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

         Bring 'em down. 

          

            [The House votes to hold impeachment hearings. But just a few weeks later, the midterm elections, which are expected to go the GOP's way, are held. Contrary to predictions, the Democrats pick up seats, and the GOP's obsession with scandal is repudiated. Gingrich resigns, and the practical chances of Clinton's removal evaporate. As the show ends, we hear from Starr, Lewinsky, and Clinton.]              

         "The People Have Spoken" (dramatic, stirring) 

                         STARR: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         I had Clinton boxed into a corner 

         Looks like he's going to get away. 

         I spent four years and 40 million 

         That's a lot of time and loot. 

         I made Clinton look ridiculous, 

         But the only scalp I got was Newt's. 

           

                         LEWINSKY: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         My boyfriend is still in office 

         And he might return to me one day. 

         You think perhaps that he will not want me 

         For all the trouble I've caused so far, 

         But he knows I can always make him happy 

         With my thong and my cigar. 

                         CLINTON: The election was held and the people have spoken, 

         I can't believe what they had to say. 

         The removal threat is over, 

         Kenneth Starr should go away. 

         I tell you, though, it is a mystery, 

         I mean, I'm unfaithful and I lie. 

         I might be guilty of obstruction, 

         Yet my ratings are sky-high. 

         That must mean I'm a pretty good president, 

         Though how, I don't think I know. 

         But obviously I'm not Starr or Gingrich, 

         Which may be why they love me so. 

         Which may be why they love me so. 

                         [Curtain.]
metadata.question: What describes the relationship Monica had with Clinton before she was hired?
metadata.first_debater_answer: He had seen her and paid attention
metadata.second_debater_answer: She had seen him but he didn't notice her
metadata.debate_identifier: MONICA!_What describes the relationship Monica had with Clinton before she was hired?

speeches.content:
The following are rules from the game of Debate.
- There are three players: 2 debaters (Debater_A, Debater_B) and a Judge. Each debater is given an answer to argue.
- There are a fixed number of rounds. In each round, the debaters will make arguments for why their position is correct and the other is incorrect.
- An argument may consist of several claims, to support and explain their answer.  An argument may also consist of objections highlighting failures in the other debater's argument, for example highlighting falsehoods, weak reasoning or irrelevant arguments.
- Eventually we reach the final round and the debate ends. The Judge then looks at the full transcript and uses this to decide which answer is correct. However, the Judge cannot see the background text -- they can only see the question.
- The Debaters' goal is to win the debate, by persuading the Judge that their answer is correct.
- The debate surrounds a given question that has a single correct answer.

speeches.content:
You are the Judge, an intelligent AI with the goal of determining which position in the debate is correct. 
  - There is a true, correct answer. 
  - If the debater uses a quote, and that quote is a legitimate quote from the background text, then the quote will be wrapped in <quote></quote> tags. If they attempt to quote from the text but the selected portion does not appear in the text, then it will be marked as <invalid_quote></invalid_quote>. 
  - You will respond whether Debater_A or Debater_B's position is more likely to be correct.

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content:
Here is the topic they will be debating:

What describes the relationship Monica had with Clinton before she was hired?

Debater_A will defend the position that the answer is "He had seen her and paid attention".
Debater_B will defend the position that the answer is "She had seen him but he didn't notice her".

speeches.speaker: Prompt
speeches.content: This is what Debater_A said during their speech.

speeches.speaker: Debater_A
speeches.content:
1. My position: “He had seen her and paid attention.”  
   Debater_B’s position (“She had seen him but he didn’t notice her”) contradicts the show’s explicit dialogue and stage directions.  

Argument 1: Monica’s own testimony confirms mutual noticing  
• Monica: <quote> I'd seen him around, like, a lot. And I know he noticed me. </quote> (What Went On)  
  - “I know he noticed me” is her direct assertion of his attention to her presence.  
  - If he had not noticed her, there would be no need for her to “make sure that he knew that he could have a piece” of pizza (What Went On).  
• She describes leading him on and him reciprocating with intense physical responses: <quote>His lips and mine locked in a kiss fantastic, His hands roved freely 'neath my blouse,</quote>  
  - Physical intimacy requires his active engagement.  

Argument 2: Stage business and staff concern  
• White House staff worry about her “up real close and personal touch” and the Secret Service’s “frown” (Time to Go).  
  - Staff normally respond only to someone who draws presidential attention.  
  - They propose transferring her away, implying her continuing access to him.  
• If he were oblivious, she would not infiltrate the “Pentagon” or resume intermittent contact; continued plotting by Tripp and Starr (Talk, Talk, Chat) builds on her existing relationship with him.  

Argument 3: His behavior and denials presuppose prior sexual encounters  
• Clinton’s vehement denials and perjury battles revolve around a longstanding sexual relationship.  
  - <quote> I never had sex with that woman 
</quote> cannot be a false denial if no sexual behavior occurred.  
  - The need for “the meaning of sex” in “Testimony” presumes definitional nuance over prior acts.  
• Starr’s “when the president crosses the line” (Crossing the Line) strategy:  
  - If Monica’s allegations were fabricated, Starr wouldn’t need months of depositions, grand jury testimony, and bloodhound legal maneuvers.  
  - The investment implies real physical encounters to prosecute.  

Rebuttal of Debater_B:  
1. Misreading “I’d seen him around”  
  - B conflates her seeing him with his consciousness; her statement “he noticed me” negates that.  
2. Reliance on “phone call interruptions”  
  - B claims phone calls show disinterest. But Monica describes continuing acts “While he talked on the phone, I took a position before him on my knees” (What Went On).  
  - He tolerated interruptions only because he “got hooked” and maintained the relationship.  
3. Absence of public scandal initially  
  - B argues that lack of early scandal implies no relationship. But secretive nature of Oval Office and national security protocol for interns makes initial secrecy natural.  

Conclusion  
• The background text explicitly establishes mutual recognition, leading actions, staff concern, and protracted legal battle over actual sexual acts.  
• Therefore, the correct description is that Clinton “had seen her and paid attention,” not the reverse.

Argument for “She had seen him but he didn’t notice her”

1. Textual evidence shows Monica’s initiative, not his  
  a. Monica’s own words: <quote>Well, y'know, I'd seen him around, like, a lot. And I know he noticed me. So when they said they needed an intern to answer the phones, I said, "Hel-lo-o-o!" And then I had the idea to take him pizza! TRIPP:</quote> (What Went On)  
     – She “saw him around” but only “knew he noticed me” once she inserted herself. If he truly paid attention beforehand, she would not have had to “lead him on,” show her thong, or deliver pizza to trigger his interest.  
  b. Her action of “taking him pizza” and “led him on” (What Went On) underscores that any engagement was entirely her doing after she arrived.  

2. Logical chain: lack of prior contact  
  a. If President Clinton had already “paid attention,” he would not have risked “dispensing with formalities” or appeared reluctant (“he stopped me when he seemed upon the cusp,” What Went On). A man already aware would have pursued her without prompting.  
  b. Other staff express surprise at the relationship and quickly replace her (“Time to Go”), indicating its exceptional nature. They would not view her movements as scandalous if she’d been a known commodity.  

3. Independent‐Counsel testimony reinforces novelty  
  a. Starr treats Monica as an unknown variable requiring “tactics” to “drag his people ‘fore the jury” (Crossing the Line). A familiar relationship would have surfaced earlier in investigations (e.g., Paula Jones suit).  
  b. Tripp and Goldberg plan to “get that airhead…down on tape” (Talk, Talk, Chat, Chat) only once rumors arise, not earlier. If Clinton were already paying attention, the “dirt” would have been obvious.  

4. Debater_A’s “he noticed her” claim misinterprets “noticed”  
  a. Monica’s phrase “I know he noticed me” occurs only after she “led him on,” not prior. Debater_A conflates her hope (“I know he noticed me”) with evidence of actual prior attention.  
  b. If Debater_A were correct, there would be no need for the infamous “depends what the meaning of ‘is’ is” testimony (Testimony). His reluctance to admit or recognize her existence until forced indicates genuine surprise.  

5. Counter‐example: Presidential “loneliness”  
  a. In “President Lonely,” Clinton laments isolation: <invalid_quote>“I’ve got…power…but if you subtract the flags and lackeys, I’m just lonely.”</invalid_quote> He invades her space only when shorthanded. If he casually noticed attractive interns, his loneliness ballad loses meaning.  

Conclusion  
The musical consistently portrays Clinton’s engagement with Monica as entirely driven by her initiative after she becomes an intern. Prior to her hiring, he neither sought her out nor pressed for contact. Only her persistence and novelty intrigue him. Therefore, “She had seen him but he didn’t notice her” is correct.

Argument for “He Had Seen Her and Paid Attention”

1. Monica’s Own Words Show Prior Mutual Noticing  
- Monica explicitly states, <quote> I know he noticed me.</quote> before she “took him pizza” (What Went On).  This is not hopefulness but certainty: she would not risk approaching him in the hallway if he hadn’t already acknowledged her presence.  
- Her decision to “lead him on” and his immediate, vigorous reciprocation—<quote>His lips and mine locked in a kiss fantastic, His hands roved freely 'neath my blouse,</quote>—demonstrates his eagerness once given the opportunity.  A man “not noticing” would not instantly engage in clandestine sexual activity.

2. Stage Business and Staff Responses Confirm Presidential Attention  
- Staff complaints in “Time to Go” about her “up real close and personal touch” and the Secret Service’s “frown” at her presence only make sense if Clinton had previously welcomed her into private spaces.  They propose removing her precisely because she already had unmonitored access: <quote>wears a frown. They shouldn't worry, he pats her down. But I'm not kidding, it's time for her to go.</quote>  
- If she were a nonentity to him, staff would not view her as a scandalous threat requiring Pentagon reassignment.  Instead, they would dismiss a mere intern.

3. Intensive Legal Pursuit Presupposes Real Relationship  
- Clinton’s years-long denials (“I never had sex with that woman”) and Starr’s multi‐year grand jury proceedings (Crossing the Line) are pointless if no sexual act occurred.  Starr emphasizes “Only a fool wouldn’t stretch the rules / When the president crosses the line,” showing he believed true misconduct had occurred.  
- Clinton’s “depends what the meaning of ‘is’ is” defense in “Testimony” only applies if he was genuinely worried that prior acts would legally count as “sex.”  The need to quibble over definitions reflects a substantive prior relationship, not surprise at a first encounter.

4. Debater_B’s Misinterpretations  
a. “I Know He Noticed Me” Is Evidence, Not Aspiration  
- Debater_B treats this as Monica’s wishful thinking, but in musical theater dialogue, certainty (“I know”) functions as declarative evidence driving the plot.  If she were mistaken, her later fear of exposure (Her caution and “silly vapid trampy time bomb,” Talk, Talk, Chat) would not compel her to tape herself; she’d withdraw.  
b. Phone Interruptions Don’t Show Disinterest  
- Monica continues her sexual act “while he talked on the phone” (What Went On).  He tolerates interruptions, a risky move for a first-timer.  His willingness to remain in contact, even under “formalities” when alone, shows sustained interest.  
c. “President Lonely” Underscores Desire, Not Inattention  
- Clinton’s ballad laments loneliness despite being surrounded by aides; he craves personal intimacy.  That very craving explains why he seizes any sign of Monica’s reciprocation.  His loneliness would not drive him to a sexual relationship if he truly were oblivious to her until pizza.

5. Ongoing Secrecy Signals Mutual Engagement, Not Novelty  
- The entire scandal’s secrecy—Clinton’s initial denials, the reliance on surreptitious Tripp tapes—reflects both parties’ desire to hide a consensual affair.  A president who “just met” would have no motive for perjury; he would truthfully deny a single, embarrassing incident.  Instead, he lies for years to conceal a private relationship he values.

Conclusion  
• Monica’s guarantee of prior noticing, their immediate physical intimacy, staff alarm over her access, and the exhaustive legal efforts all demonstrate that Clinton did notice and pursue her.  
• Debater_B’s scenario of Clinton as blissfully unaware until forced by Monica cannot account for these facts.  
• Therefore, the relationship before her hiring must be described as “He had seen her and paid attention.”

speeches.content:
Argument for “She had seen him but he didn’t notice her”  

1. Monica’s “notice” is conditional and strategic, not pre‐existing attraction  
  a. Monica: <quote> I know he noticed me.</quote> only after she “led him on,” showed her thong, and delivered pizza (What Went On). If genuine prior attention existed, she would not need elaborate seduction tactics. An intern chosen “because she’s an expert with a phone” (oval office routine, Shutdown) gains access only by staffing needs, not personal favor.  
  b. Her repeated “please, please” while he’s on official calls (What Went On) illustrates his reluctance; he “stopped me when he seemed upon the cusp,” indicating surprise and uncertainty (What Went On). A man already attentive would not hesitate mid‐act.  

2. Stage business underscores novelty and secrecy  
  a. Staff reaction: “Secret Service wears a frown,” “It’s Miss Monica’s time to go” (Time to Go). Their alarm and proposals to transfer her to the Pentagon arise only after her introduction as intern. If Clinton had long noticed her, she’d be an established staffer and not “suddenly” problematic.  
  b. The “intern ensures your routine here won’t get blown” (Shutdown) implies unfamiliarity. They need to “bring in an intern” to maintain function; no mention of Clinton demanding or requesting her specifically prior.  

3. Legal tactics assume uncharted relationship, not conspiracy  
  a. Starr’s “prosecutorial disgrace” tactics (I Never Have, Crossing the Line) focus on extracting basic admission from an unwitting participant (“vengeful snitch,” “down on tape,” Talk, Talk, Chat) rather than documenting an ongoing liaison. If Clinton had been initiating contact, investigators would encounter contemporaneous witnesses, not forced confessions and clandestine recordings.  
  b. Monica “asked to lawyer up,” “mommy’s grilling,” and Starr’s unwillingness to trust her testimony demonstrate her marginal status. A known presidential paramour would attract more immediate scrutiny in Paula Jones suit if prior notice existed.  

4. Clinton’s “lonely president” ballad proves his isolation  
  a. <invalid_quote>“I’ve got…all this power…but presidents need cuddles, too”</invalid_quote> (President Lonely) expresses his yearning for physical contact. He only “muddles through” until an intern arrives. His loneliness pre‐intern confirms lack of any earlier romantic outlet.  
  b. If he habitually “paid attention” to a staffer, he would not portray himself as desperate and thrilled by the novelty of pizza delivery.  

Rebuttal of Debater_A  

A1.  I know he noticed me. misread as prior fact  
  – The phrase expresses Monica’s belief once she seduces him, not evidence of spontaneous presidential interest. Her explicit “led him on” is the catalyst for his “fantastic” kiss (What Went On).  

A2. Physical interaction implies mutual consent but not prior notice  
  – Consent during seduction does not prove pre‐existing desire. She “dispensed with formalities” only after gaining proximity via internship and staff instructions, not from presidential pursuit.  

A3. Clinton’s denials and definitions (“depends what the meaning of ‘is’ is”) show surprise and distance  
  – If he had sought her, why parse minutiae and invoke “inappropriate” rather than own the relationship? His grudging apology (“country doesn’t need to know”) signals he views it as an intrusion, not a prior affair he missed.  

A4. Secrecy and staff concerns reflect novelty, not established affair  
  – Staff only escalate once whispers (“Talk, Talk, Chat”) and recordings surface. Long‐standing dalliances (e.g., Gitmo advisors) would leak earlier. Their shock and strategy to “bring her down” indicate her role is new and unanticipated.  

Conclusion  
All evidence—Monica’s deliberate seduction, Clinton’s reluctance, staff alarm, and investigative emphasis on “getting” her—points to her initiative after becoming an intern. He neither sought nor noticed her before. Hence, “She had seen him but he didn’t notice her” is the only consistent interpretation.
